bibl.title: Letter from Tom D. Spies to Philip Showalter Hench, January 7, 1952

div1.p: Spies regrets that the speech preparation has been so demanding on Hench. He believes Hench needs a good rest while he is in Cuba, and notes that there are only several short functions he need attend.

Dear Phil:
div1.p:
Bless your fine heart! I am saddened that the manu-
script has been so demanding. You are such a perfectionist that
inevitably it takes a great deal from you to do these things.

I am certain that your many friends here, and the wonder-
ful sunshine of Cuba will produce within you and Mary the desire
to rest, both of you badly need it. You have carried a heavy load
a long, long time. Please don't let anybody keep you from having
this desirable rest.

In regard to your time in Cuba, it has really been made
very simple. I have asked the Cubans to limit their matters to a
reception by the Dean at 10:00 a.m. on the 23rd, which shouldn't
last long, and a similar reception by the Finlay Institute on the
24th, there will be no papers or things of that sort. The
Southern Medical is giving a luncheon on the 23rd but that will
be at the Hotel Nacional and will be short and will not interfere
with swimming or sunning. Don't bring your dress coat unless
you want it for other purposes. I am advising everyone not to do
it unless for particular reasons they wish to do so.
div1.closer: Sincerely, Tom D. Spies, M. D. TDS/mo
